description:
Delivered my first Committee of Supply Debate response in Parliament earlier today as Minister for Education. It was a long but productive debate, and I thank all MPs who submitted cuts for the robust and thoughtful discussion. 

There is no end to the betterment of our education system. But Covid-19 has added greater urgency to our work, and helped to crystallise our priorities moving forward. MOE is seizing this window of opportunity to equip our students with a broader range of competencies, develop more diverse and flexible pathways of learning through life, and uplift every child regardless of their starting point. 

#linkinbio to read the full speech

#MOECOS2021 #LearnforLife

description:
Wanted to share this festive tune by the students at Lakeside Primary, to wish everyone a happy Chap Goh Mei!

Chinese New Year celebrations have been relatively muted this year due to Covid-19, but Iâ€™m glad it hasnâ€™t dampened spirits, especially for our students who have gamely kept up with mask-wearing and safe management measures in schools. 

There is still a long journey ahead of us, but step by step, we can emerge stronger together. May the Year of the Ox usher in strength and fortitude for us all!

He also had some ideas on how we can improve learning in schools! My repertoire of riddles has definitely grown after this - watch to find out what I mean.

comments: I recently read this book called â€œThe House on Silat Roadâ€, by Si-Hoe SS to my 9 year old child. Talks about their life from 1941-1945. Very interesting and real life story on their time during the Japanese occupation. I can feel that my child was bewildered that Singapore had such a history and it was a very good history lesson for her. Makes her appreciate the peace and prosperity that we are enjoying now. She inquired more about total defence day, the significance of it, the sounding of the public warning system, the purpose behind it.Great book that perhaps schools can introduce the children to. Lest we forget.
description:
å±…å®‰æ€å± - to remain vigilant in times of peace. We learnt this through a painful time in our history - the Japanese Occupation, and it remains a very relevant lesson today as we grapple with the current Covid-19 crisis. 

Many thanks to the @sccci.official for organising the War Memorial Service for the past 54 years, and for launching an e-book this year capturing the stories of those who had suffered through the Occupation and significance of the Civilian War Memorial. 

The best homage we can pay to our forefathers and pioneers is to continue to hold fast to the spirit and values of Total Defence, as we work to overcome this pandemic, and build a better Singapore.

Many thanks to the @sccci.official for organising the War Memorial Service for the past 54 years, and for launching an e-book this year capturing the stories of those who had suffered through the Occupation and significance of the Civilian War Memorial. 

The best homage we can pay to our forefathers and pioneers is to continue to hold fast to the spirit and values of Total Defence, as we work to overcome this pandemic, and build a better Singapore.

Itâ€™s #å¹´é™¤å¤• today, and it also happens to be the International Day of Women and Girls in Science. When I saw the theme for this year â€“ â€œWomen Scientists at the forefront of the fight against COVID-19â€, I was reminded of Dr Yang YinPing, whom I met at the launch of URAâ€™s â€œOur Digital Worldâ€ exhibition in 2016, when I was Minister for National Development. 

At that time, Dr Yang shared how she, together with her A*STAR colleagues, worked with MOH to use social networking sites to monitor the outbreak of avian flu in China. Fast forward to 2020, and Dr Yang is once again using her expertise in sentiment analysis to analyse global sentiments around COVID-19 on Twitter. Her team has observed different emotional responses to the pandemic across different countries, and their ongoing research to find out why may provide valuable insights into how we can better handle such crises in future. 

Also looking forward to enjoy a reunion meal today with one of the very first women in Science I knew growing up â€“ my mother, who was also my Science teacher in school ğŸ™‚

#CelebratingSGWomen #womeninscience

description:
At todayâ€™s IPS SG Perspectives Conference. It has been a while since I attended an event like this. But with pre-entry rapid antigen tests and strict distancing rules we can ensure itâ€™s safe for everyone. 

The theme of the conference was aptly titled â€œResetâ€. Indeed we must be prepared to reexamine all our operating assumptions and paradigms to prepare for a post-covid world. In particular I shared my thoughts on the resets in policy thinking, lifestyles and mindsets that we need for the future. My hope is that we can all work towards a fairer and more equal society, a greener Singapore, and a nation with a stronger spirit of solidarity and shared purpose. 

#linkinbio for the full speech.

description: We are seeing more new infected cases in the community in recent days. Our contact tracers are working hard to identify all possible contacts, ring-fence the potential cases and prevent them from spreading further.  We are monitoring the situation carefully and considering if additional measures are necessary to ensure the infection remains under control. Meanwhile please cooperate with all the safe management measures and do your part to reduce transmission risks. The virus is still circulating silently within our community and we cannot afford to let our guard down.

While we want to keep it open, we know that if a person we let in has a new variant of the virus, as long as the person continues to breathe, it will get into the community, no matter what kind of SHN, etc that we do. Only 10m doses needed to vaccinate the population, letâ€™s speed it up for those who want it and accelerate the herd immunity.

description:
Goodbye 2020! There are no words to describe the year. Just this image of the virus. It wreaked havoc across the globe and brought everything to a standstill. Our lives changed completely. We will never forget what weâ€™ve been through.

What will 2021 be like? No one can tell. But one thing is certain: the virus is still with us, and circulating in our community. The family cluster we detected today is a sobering reminder of the need for all of us to remain vigilant. 

So as we welcome the new year, letâ€™s do so with some circumspection and reflection. We still have much to do in the fight against Covid. Keeping the infection under control while we re-open safely, and implementing the vaccination programme smoothly will be two major priorities in the year ahead.

So if I have a wish for 2021, itâ€™s that we continue to stay united, and we work hard to complete our mission to defeat Covid-19 together as Team Singapore!

What will 2021 be like? No one can tell. But one thing is certain: the virus is still with us, and circulating in our community. The family cluster we detected today is a sobering reminder of the need for all of us to remain vigilant. 

So as we welcome the new year, letâ€™s do so with some circumspection and reflection. We still have much to do in the fight against Covid. Keeping the infection under control while we re-open safely, and implementing the vaccination programme smoothly will be two major priorities in the year ahead.

So if I have a wish for 2021, itâ€™s that we continue to stay united, and we work hard to complete our mission to defeat Covid-19 together as Team Singapore!

comments: Happy New Year! Let's send all the positive energy to coming year. 2021 will be promising ğŸ˜ğŸ™

MOE welcomed Phase 3 with the Appointment & Appreciation Ceremony for Principals today. Although all of us had to go through pre-event testing, it was quick and painless, and we were glad to be able to celebrate the achievements of our Principals in person, together. 

30 of our senior educators are retiring, sharing between them over 1,000 years in education! Thank you for touching so many lives during your years of service, and for your immense contributions to our education system. 

Congratulations to our newly appointed and rotated Principals - lead with conviction and purpose, and take heart that you are not alone in this leadership journey.

comments: Iâ€™m so excited when I opened my wallet and I saw my payment of $25,000 what a boost! You are the type of manager I have always wanted.Thanks so much for the payment @jackson_trading_investment

comments: I'm thankful for our teachers and principals, especially those who were part of my children's lives, they've complemented our parenting efforts with good education.

Phase 3 begins today. Families will now have the chance to gather in a larger group of 8, and enjoy some meaningful time together.

But please remember: there are still rules in Phase 3. So comply with the measures and do not let your guard down. Around the world, some experts are already warning about a post-seasonal surge in cases, as people are ignoring the restrictions and flocking together for festive celebrations. We must not allow that to happen here.

I thank the majority of residents here who are doing their part. Unfortunately there are a few who continue to disregard the rules. Some book multiple tables in restaurants; others hold large parties in their homes. We will step up enforcement checks, and will take firm actions against these breaches, even for first-time offences - business outlets will be closed, individuals fined, and as highlighted before, those who are work-pass holders risk getting their passes revoked.

Letâ€™s stay focused and get through the next few months safely, until we are able to get everyone in Singapore vaccinated.

description:
Many of you would have collected your reusable face masks from vending machines nationwide. During my visit to SUTD last week, I met the founders of BEEP, the system that powers these vending machines. Besides powering the mask vending machines, BEEP works on systems to enable low-cost mobile and cashless payments.

It was exciting to see many great ideas incubating at SUTD. The students receive excellent support and training at the university, which promotes design thinking and creativity. Looking forward to more good work done by our young thinkers and future-makers!

Our young volunteers are making sure that online shopping and getting good deals during sales like #1111 are no longer limited to the younger generation. Sembawang Secondary students conducted online workshops for a group of seniors to teach them how to grocery shop on Redmart and navigate apps like Shopee - very useful for this season! They have been teaching seniors digital skills face to face for the past 3 years, but have brought their workshops online when COVID-19 hit. 

Great to see our students giving back and â€˜teachingâ€™ so enthusiastically. With some practice, their new 'students' could well be ready for #1212 too!

Saw this on my desk this morning - a nice surprise from my staff to mark #100days at @moesingapore - thank you!

It's been quite a whirlwind of activity since joining the ministry, but Iâ€™ve enjoyed heading #backtoschool, meeting with students and educators, and getting a better sense of how our policies are working. One thing that has not changed (since I was last in MOE 9 years ago) is the deep sense of mission and passion the MOE team has - to continually improve learning and teaching, and to bring out the best in every child. 

Our education reforms are underway and the next phase will focus on implementing these changes effectively and well, while ensuring the safety of our schools amidst this pandemic. The effort behind this should not be understated, and Iâ€™m looking forward to working with colleagues, educators, students and parents to make sure we get it right. Hereâ€™s to the next #100days and more!

description:
Saw this on my desk this morning - a nice surprise from my staff to mark #100days at @moesingapore - thank you!

It's been quite a whirlwind of activity since joining the ministry, but Iâ€™ve enjoyed heading #backtoschool, meeting with students and educators, and getting a better sense of how our policies are working. One thing that has not changed (since I was last in MOE 9 years ago) is the deep sense of mission and passion the MOE team has - to continually improve learning and teaching, and to bring out the best in every child. 

Our education reforms are underway and the next phase will focus on implementing these changes effectively and well, while ensuring the safety of our schools amidst this pandemic. The effort behind this should not be understated, and Iâ€™m looking forward to working with colleagues, educators, students and parents to make sure we get it right. Hereâ€™s to the next #100days and more!

description: Been slowly settling into the office over the past few months, and unpacked this sculpture yesterday. I received it as a farewell gift in 2012 from DPM Heng Swee Keat. He was then Minister for Education, and I was supporting him as the Senior Minister of State. It followed me from office to office ever since. Named â€œSymphony of the Seaâ€, the six Bukit View Primary students who created it imagined themselves as tiny sea creatures swimming amongst the corals, living in harmony with one another. It reminds me of the vibrancy of our distinctive culture, and the energy and optimism of our young ones :)

comments: Best to invite those who have experienced it intensely and is clinically proven - and what they did to ultimately recover
description:
There have been more conversations around mental health recently, especially among youth. Yeo Wei Hong, Serangoon JC alumnus, and Ding Ruo Kun, Singapore Polytechnic student, are part of a passionate group of young people who are sharing their perspectives on youth mental health with MOE. They are also working with us to figure out creative solutions.

Here are their nuggets of advice for peers who are facing stressful times â€“ believe in yourself, and take things slow and steady, step by step, when you feel overwhelmed. Wei Hong is also a big fan of running regularly to clear his mind. As someone who enjoys taking walks in our parks, I agree that spending time outdoors is an excellent way to de-stress.

If you're stressed, do talk to someone you trust. We can all lend a listening ear to a friend or loved one.

Saw this poster in the lift at Yew Tee and learnt about @scratchbac_sg, a community initiative started by three @SUTDsg students who were inspired by essential workers and volunteers, and wanted to use their skills to help in their own way. 

Itâ€™s a social resource sharing platform that connects people with the community around them, making it convenient for neighbours to share resources and help each other. Users have offered to help their neighbours print documents and explain medications, look for running buddies, and give away items like extra masks and even microwaves and bicycles. 

Very glad to see youths like Jerry Neo, Princeton Poh, and Cheryl Low leverage technology to come up with innovative ideas to contribute back to society!

#SGUnited

It was a pleasure to join Mr Brajesh Panth, Chief, Education Sector Group of Asian Development Bank and Assoc Prof Suzaina Kadir from LKYSPP for the Asia Thinker Series virtual dialogue last evening to discuss the future of education post COVID-19.

A key topic we discussed was the role of technology in education. There are many views about how best we should utilise and integrate technology in teaching and learning. But the starting premise should always be centred on human needs, and that of our students.

We must therefore work to harness technology in a way that supports our studentsâ€™ learning needs, well-being and holistic development. This way, technology becomes a force for good in education: to enable, inspire, and uplift every child, and to help prepare them for a rapidly changing future.

Attended my first G20 Education Ministersâ€™ Meeting online yesterday evening, which Singapore was invited to participate in. 

All the Education Ministers are grappling with how to reopen and resume schools safely during this pandemic. But the silver lining amidst this crisis is the opportunity to reimagine and transform education. We have seen how technological tools can be harnessed to improve education dramatically. So we are all looking at new models of hybrid learning that involve an integration of face-to-face with home-based learning. 

I shared with my counterparts Singaporeâ€™s experience, and also learnt a lot from the insights gleaned from other countries. Global cooperation has never been more pertinent as we combat COVID-19, and the G20 stands as an important platform for such cooperation.

#G20 #G20SaudiArabia

But am glad we can still connect virtually and have a meaningful celebration. Many thanks to all our grassroots volunteers for your many years of dedicated service to residents!

Swearing in of MPs across two venues at the reopening of Parliament last night. The work of this Government begins â€œunder the shadow of Covid-19â€, as President @halimahyacob puts it. We must focus our energies on the critical tasks of fighting the virus, and securing jobs for Singaporeans. But beyond the crisis, we also need to strengthen our social safety nets, improve social mobility and forge a stronger national identity.

These times have truly tested us as a government, and as a nation. For me, personally, it has reinforced my conviction and resolve to serve.  We all want Singapore to be the best home for our people. Everyone must have views on how to do things. But with every decision, there will be difficult trade-offs. As an elected government, we have a responsibility to think through the issues, and govern for all our people. We need to work with everyone to get things done, and do things right, because the consequences affect every Singaporean. Now with more opposition voices in Parliament, I look forward to both sides of the House working responsibly and together - to secure the best for our people, and a better future for Singapore.

#examseason is coming up, and there may be some concern given the COVID-19 situation. MOE and SEAB will make arrangements so that as many students as possible can take the year-end written exams in a safe manner. For those who miss the exams for valid reasons, they can apply for special consideration. 

Exams are important milestones, but there is no need to stress too much. Prepare well and put your best foot forward. All the best!

Inspired to #BeTheLight after watching this song beautifully performed by a virtual choir of 200 students - a wonderful dedication to Singapore!

National Day will be celebrated differently in our schools this year because of COVID-19. But as always, we will find new, creative ways to come together and emerge stronger. 

#SYFgoesOnline #SGUnited #SingaporeTogether

description:
#NursesDay holds greater significance this year in light of our ongoing fight against COVID-19.

I was honoured to pay tribute to a group of NUH nurses this afternoon at @gardensbythebay. They have all been working so hard to take care of our patients. Hence GB offered them a chance to enjoy the Flower Dome and Cloud Forest, as a way to show our appreciation and gratitude. 

#HappyNursesDay to all! Thank you so much for your service and contributions to Singapore.

The writ of election has been issued and Parliament dissolved. But the work of the Multi-Ministry Taskforce does not stop and remains a priority throughout this period. We continue to meet regularly, and to update our plans and strategies to control the infection and keep everyone safe. 
Yesterday, we announced our plans to further expand testing in the community. From 1 July, we will test all individuals aged 13 and above who are diagnosed with acute respiratory infection when they see a doctor. We will also test additional specific groups who may face greater exposure risks such as the frontline staff interacting with travellers at the airport; as well as vulnerable groups who need more protection, specifically the seniors living in communal facilities and shelters.
The expansion of systematic testing in the community will allow us to enhance and tighten disease surveillance, detect the virus early and reduce the risk of further transmission.

comments: Should penalty for business owners who violating
description:
Itâ€™s the second day of our Phase 2 re-opening, and the majority of businesses and individuals are cooperating with the measures to resume activities safely. But unfortunately a few have acted very irresponsibly. They will be taken to task. 
Last night, the authorities were alerted to large crowds gathering around the Outdoor Refreshment Areas (ORA) and on the road along Lor Mambong in Holland Village.  Based on their inspections, the crowds were largely gathering outside one restaurant, namely the British Indian Curry Hut. We will close the restaurant with immediate effect.
All ORAs along Lor Mambong will also be removed. So F&B outlets along this stretch will have to ensure that their customers dine only within their premises, and are not eating or drinking outside. 
Enforcement officers have also issued fines to several individuals in the vicinity last night for violating safe distancing rules. Investigations are ongoing for other possible breaches.
Our officers will continue their patrols islandwide, especially in popular nightspots, and will take immediate actions against any individuals or business flouting the safe distancing rules.

Based on their inspections, the crowds were largely gathering outside one restaurant, namely the British Indian Curry Hut. We will close the restaurant with immediate effect.
All ORAs along Lor Mambong will also be removed. So F&B outlets along this stretch will have to ensure that their customers dine only within their premises, and are not eating or drinking outside. 
Enforcement officers have also issued fines to several individuals in the vicinity last night for violating safe distancing rules. Investigations are ongoing for other possible breaches.
Our officers will continue their patrols islandwide, especially in popular nightspots, and will take immediate actions against any individuals or business flouting the safe distancing rules.

Phase 2 begins tomorrow. I know many of you have been eagerly waiting for this. But there is no need to rush to go out. You have plenty of time to do so. So please keep your guard up, and continue to stay disciplined and vigilant. 
We are allowing gatherings of not more than 5 people. But do exercise personal responsibility and continue to keep your daily contacts small, and preferably limited to a regular circle of close contacts. If you are dining out, put your masks back on right away after eating. Avoid lingering around at the table and talking without your masks. 
Public officials will be out and about to enforce the rules. But a safe and sustainable Phase 2 re-opening cannot be achieved through rules alone. Some people may even be thinking of ways to outsmart the rules. But in the end, you and your loved ones will end up paying the price. As my colleague Mr Gan Kim Yong said, you can fool the rule, but you canâ€™t fool the virus. So itâ€™s in all our interest to cooperate fully with the measures and comply with the spirit of the regulations (not just the letter of the law).

If you are dining out, put your masks back on right away after eating. Avoid lingering around at the table and talking without your masks. 
Public officials will be out and about to enforce the rules. But a safe and sustainable Phase 2 re-opening cannot be achieved through rules alone. Some people may even be thinking of ways to outsmart the rules. But in the end, you and your loved ones will end up paying the price. As my colleague Mr Gan Kim Yong said, you can fool the rule, but you canâ€™t fool the virus. So itâ€™s in all our interest to cooperate fully with the measures and comply with the spirit of the regulations (not just the letter of the law).

Phase 2 begins tomorrow. I know many of you have been eagerly waiting for this. But there is no need to rush to go out. You have plenty of time to do so. So please keep your guard up, and continue to stay disciplined and vigilant.

We are allowing gatherings of not more than 5 people. But do exercise personal responsibility and continue to keep your daily contacts small, and preferably limited to a regular circle of close contacts. If you are dining out, put your masks back on right away after eating. Avoid lingering around at the table and talking without your masks. 
Public officials will be out and about to enforce the rules. But a safe and sustainable Phase 2 re-opening cannot be achieved through rules alone. Some people may even be thinking of ways to outsmart the rules. But in the end, you and your loved ones will end up paying the price. As my colleague Mr Gan Kim Yong said, you can fool the rule, but you canâ€™t fool the virus. So itâ€™s in all our interest to cooperate fully with the measures and comply with the spirit of the regulations (not just the letter of the law).

Singapore will be entering Phase 2 of reopening after 18 June 2359. This means that from Friday onwards, almost all businesses will be able to re-open, be it retail, F&B dining-in or personalised consumer services. The key requirement is that individuals must maintain safe distancing of at least 1 m at all times, and if thatâ€™s not feasible (eg when dining at a table), then each group will be limited to a maximum of 5 persons. Sports, gyms, playgrounds, and other public facilities will open, as will similar facilities in condominiums and clubs. Small group gatherings of up to any 5 persons can also resume, and households may receive up to 5 visitors at any time. 
There are a small number of activities that will take more time to resume. These are activities where large numbers of people are likely to come into close contact, often in enclosed spaces and for prolonged periods of time. They include religious services and congregations; large-scale events and venues; and entertainment outlets like bars, clubs and karaoke outlets. We will continue to work with these organisations and business owners on the safe management measures that are needed before they can open.
Phase 2 is a significant step forward in our reopening process. But please do not treat this as a signal to relax and let our guard down. 
Businesses must take the rules seriously. Do not rush to open if you are not ready, because you will be putting your own customers and employees at risk. All of us must continue to exercise individual and social responsibility. Thereâ€™s no need to rush to go out this weekend. We should continue to limit our close contacts, even if we can now meet in groups. As customers, we should also be discerning about the establishments we patronise, and insist on high safety standards everywhere we go.

Letâ€™s continue to work together on this collective journey to achieve a Covid-safe Singapore!

description:
Singapore will be entering Phase 2 of reopening after 18 June 2359. This means that from Friday onwards, almost all businesses will be able to re-open, be it retail, F&B dining-in or personalised consumer services. The key requirement is that individuals must maintain safe distancing of at least 1 m at all times, and if thatâ€™s not feasible (eg when dining at a table), then each group will be limited to a maximum of 5 persons. Sports, gyms, playgrounds, and other public facilities will open, as will similar facilities in condominiums and clubs. Small group gatherings of up to any 5 persons can also resume, and households may receive up to 5 visitors at any time. 
There are a small number of activities that will take more time to resume. These are activities where large numbers of people are likely to come into close contact, often in enclosed spaces and for prolonged periods of time. They include religious services and congregations; large-scale events and venues; and entertainment outlets like bars, clubs and karaoke outlets. We will continue to work with these organisations and business owners on the safe management measures that are needed before they can open.
Phase 2 is a significant step forward in our reopening process. But please do not treat this as a signal to relax and let our guard down. 
Businesses must take the rules seriously. Do not rush to open if you are not ready, because you will be putting your own customers and employees at risk. All of us must continue to exercise individual and social responsibility. Thereâ€™s no need to rush to go out this weekend. We should continue to limit our close contacts, even if we can now meet in groups. As customers, we should also be discerning about the establishments we patronise, and insist on high safety standards everywhere we go.

Letâ€™s continue to work together on this collective journey to achieve a Covid-safe Singapore!

All of us must continue to exercise individual and social responsibility. Thereâ€™s no need to rush to go out this weekend. We should continue to limit our close contacts, even if we can now meet in groups. As customers, we should also be discerning about the establishments we patronise, and insist on high safety standards everywhere we go.

Letâ€™s continue to work together on this collective journey to achieve a Covid-safe Singapore!

Singapore will be entering Phase 2 of reopening after 18 June 2359. This means that from Friday onwards, almost all businesses will be able to re-open, be it retail, F&B dining-in or personalised consumer services. The key requirement is that individuals must maintain safe distancing of at least 1 m at all times, and if thatâ€™s not feasible (eg when dining at a table), then each group will be limited to a maximum of 5 persons. Sports, gyms, playgrounds, and other public facilities will open, as will similar facilities in condominiums and clubs. Small group gatherings of up to any 5 persons can also resume, and households may receive up to 5 visitors at any time. 
There are a small number of activities that will take more time to resume. These are activities where large numbers of people are likely to come into close contact, often in enclosed spaces and for prolonged periods of time. They include religious services and congregations; large-scale events and venues; and entertainment outlets like bars, clubs and karaoke outlets. We will continue to work with these organisations and business owners on the safe management measures that are needed before they can open.
Phase 2 is a significant step forward in our reopening process. But please do not treat this as a signal to relax and let our guard down. 
Businesses must take the rules seriously. Do not rush to open if you are not ready, because you will be putting your own customers and employees at risk. All of us must continue to exercise individual and social responsibility. Thereâ€™s no need to rush to go out this weekend. We should continue to limit our close contacts, even if we can now meet in groups. As customers, we should also be discerning about the establishments we patronise, and insist on high safety standards everywhere we go.

Letâ€™s continue to work together on this collective journey to achieve a Covid-safe Singapore!

Spoke last night about our plans to adapt and live with Covid-19. To re-open safely, we've strengthened our testing and contact tracing capabilities. In the longer-term, an important part of the solution is a vaccine. If and when a vaccine becomes available, we will make sure that every Singaporean who needs it gets it, and at an affordable price. 
But it will take a long time for any vaccine to be ready.  So we have to be realistic and gird ourselves for the challenges ahead. We can no longer go back to life before the circuit breaker. Our expectations, lifestyles and norms will have to change. All of us - businesses, organisations, and individuals - will have to make adjustments to the way we do things, and some transitions will be difficult.  But as one united people, we will get through this together, and overcome this crisis of our generation.

The full clip of the speech is available on my FB page and on the Gov.Sg YouTube site 
#SGUnited
#SingaporeTogether

Spoke last night about our plans to adapt and live with Covid-19. To re-open safely, we've strengthened our testing and contact tracing capabilities. In the longer-term, an important part of the solution is a vaccine. If and when a vaccine becomes available, we will make sure that every Singaporean who needs it gets it, and at an affordable price. 
But it will take a long time for any vaccine to be ready.  So we have to be realistic and gird ourselves for the challenges ahead. We can no longer go back to life before the circuit breaker. Our expectations, lifestyles and norms will have to change. All of us - businesses, organisations, and individuals - will have to make adjustments to the way we do things, and some transitions will be difficult.  But as one united people, we will get through this together, and overcome this crisis of our generation.

The full clip of the speech is available on my FB page and on the Gov.Sg YouTube site 
#SGUnited
#SingaporeTogether

description:
The Covid-19 pandemic has exacted a heavy toll on our people - not just on those who are ill, but also on our frontliners who face the risks of the coronavirus daily, and on the jobs and livelihoods of so many. 
As PM @leehsienloong shared in his national message, this is the crisis of a generation.  It has been 5 months since the start of the outbreak. But this fight is far from over. We have to be prepared for more difficulties and disruptions in the next few years, with many uncertainties ahead. But as long as we remain united and resilient, we can emerge stronger from the crisis, and make the Singapore spirit flourish in the world!

comments: Thank you Minister. Remote work must remain the default. Where employees can work from home and who were able to do so during the CB, and employers "insist" for this group of workers to work from the office, the Govt may wish to  mandate that older workers perhaps aged 50 and above in this category must be allowed to work from home and/or work on rotational basis from home. Remote work  arrangements will be the default for a considerable amount of time, beyond Phase 1, hence some sort of  regulation ought to be put in place. Many employees may not speak up for fear of losing their job and simply comply with the employers instructions to return to the office.

Today I already saw a number of people not bothering to wear their masks properly. Seriously if this virus is more deadly, we would be dead by now. comments: Thank you so much Minister Wong for all your dedications and tireless efforts to ensure that most of our Covid-19 cases are now  contained. Together, we shall stay United as ONE NATION, ONE SINGAPURA ğŸ†ğŸ†ğŸ†ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡¬
description:
Many thanks to all who have worked hard over the past few weeks to bring down infection rates in the community.  Because of our collective efforts, we can now exit the circuit breaker and resume activities in phases starting from 2 June. 
The first phase of re-opening will be done in a careful and calibrated manner. More Singaporeans will be able to return to work, and students will go back to school. But many restrictions will still be in place. I know some were hoping to be able to go out freely - to start dining out and meeting their friends. Unfortunately, all this will have to wait. 
I hope everyone understands why we have to be cautious. We cannot risk the virus flaring up again. We also must not sacrifice all the efforts that weâ€™ve put in over the last few weeks to bring the outbreak under control. 
Some businesses will remain closed in the first phase. They include retail shops and those offering personalised services. The government will continue to extend support to these businesses and their workers. DPM @hengsweekeat will announce the details of these support measures in Parliament next week. 
We expect to be in Phase 1 for a few weeks. If the infection rate in the community remains low and stable, and the situation in the dormitories remains under control, then we will be able to move to Phase 2, where we will allow social activities and F&B dining in small groups, and re-open more consumer-facing businesses, as well as public spaces and sports facilities. 
So we will need everyone to cooperate and do your part during this first phase of re-opening. Continue to practise good personal hygiene and social responsibility. Letâ€™s stay disciplined and focussed, so that we can allow a broader range of activities to resume in good time.

comments: Thank you Minister. But the 2 visitors limit to Grandparents place does not make sense for those of us when grandparents help to fetch and look after the kids after school (3 kids in preschool in my case) and cook dinner for the kiddos and us (the parents). Especially now that we cannot dine out.

If the infection rate in the community remains low and stable, and the situation in the dormitories remains under control, then we will be able to move to Phase 2, where we will allow social activities and F&B dining in small groups, and re-open more consumer-facing businesses, as well as public spaces and sports facilities. 
So we will need everyone to cooperate and do your part during this first phase of re-opening. Continue to practise good personal hygiene and social responsibility. Letâ€™s stay disciplined and focussed, so that we can allow a broader range of activities to resume in good time.

If the infection rate in the community remains low and stable, and the situation in the dormitories remains under control, then we will be able to move to Phase 2, where we will allow social activities and F&B dining in small groups, and re-open more consumer-facing businesses, as well as public spaces and sports facilities. 
So we will need everyone to cooperate and do your part during this first phase of re-opening. Continue to practise good personal hygiene and social responsibility. Letâ€™s stay disciplined and focussed, so that we can allow a broader range of activities to resume in good time.

comments: It is not good idea to end it. Our cases still very high. ğŸ˜
description:
As we approach the end of the circuit breaker, we are now preparing for the next phase and considering what activities can resume in a safe manner.  We will do so in a very careful and calibrated manner. It wonâ€™t simply be a return to life before the circuit breaker. 
For example, in the construction sector, we will only re-start with a few projects and insist on very tight end-to-end safeguards for these projects. The safeguards include requiring all the workers involved in a project to be housed together (instead of being at multiple dormitories); safe distancing measures at the work sites; and periodic testing of the workers (at 2 week intervals). We expect only about 5% of the construction workforce to work on these projects, and will scale up over time as the industry gains confidence and experience with the measures. 
We will apply this same calibrated approach in how we resume normal activities, be it at work, schools, or in our social settings. In other words, donâ€™t expect 100% resumption of activities after 1 June. On the contrary, be fully prepared that many of the current restrictions and measures we have today will continue for some time, so as to keep our family members and loved ones safe. 
A controlled and phased exit from the circuit breaker will require patience and discipline from all of us. We must all do our part to control the spread of the virus and ensure that it does not flare up again.

The safeguards include requiring all the workers involved in a project to be housed together (instead of being at multiple dormitories); safe distancing measures at the work sites; and periodic testing of the workers (at 2 week intervals). We expect only about 5% of the construction workforce to work on these projects, and will scale up over time as the industry gains confidence and experience with the measures. 
We will apply this same calibrated approach in how we resume normal activities, be it at work, schools, or in our social settings. In other words, donâ€™t expect 100% resumption of activities after 1 June. On the contrary, be fully prepared that many of the current restrictions and measures we have today will continue for some time, so as to keep our family members and loved ones safe. 
A controlled and phased exit from the circuit breaker will require patience and discipline from all of us. We must all do our part to control the spread of the virus and ensure that it does not flare up again.

What rights do you have to destroy peopleâ€™s livelihoods?

Over 3,000 healthcare professionals have volunteered so far in our fight against COVID-19. These professionals come from all walks of life, from medical staff in the private sector, retired medical professionals, and those who are medically trained but no longer practicing. 
On this Labour Day, I thank all our essential workers and frontline officers for their hard work and sacrifices in these trying times. Together, we will overcome.

On this Labour Day, I thank all our essential workers and frontline officers for their hard work and sacrifices in these trying times. Together, we will overcome.

comments: Really amazing and hats off to the health workers and the government of Singapore, in the way this crisis  has been handled. As a expat working in the country and having worked in three other countries and travelled to many others. This city country which is home to us now never fails to amaze me. Singapore mortality rate is among the lowest and if you calculate it in percentage terms arguably Lowe than the world average for annual death rates with normal pneumonia, that speaks volumes of the dedication of health workers, their professionalism and the treatment regimen that they seem to have evolved as we battle this pandemic. We are all so proud of you!

Blessed Good Friday to all our Christian friends. 
COVID-19 has completely changed our daily routines and rituals. But itâ€™s very heartening to see how Singaporeans are rising to the challenge and adapting to the new requirements. As places of worship are closed, many are now tuning in to online services and masses. 
Stay home, keep safe, and have a blessed long weekend everyone!

Blessed Good Friday to all our Christian friends. 
COVID-19 has completely changed our daily routines and rituals. But itâ€™s very heartening to see how Singaporeans are rising to the challenge and adapting to the new requirements. As places of worship are closed, many are now tuning in to online services and masses. 
Stay home, keep safe, and have a blessed long weekend everyone!

description: Visited Changi Airport with Minister @gankimyong last week to meet our frontline workers, from immigration to healthcare, security and transport. They work hard to ensure that all returnees to Singapore are screened and isolated for 14-days, be it at home or in dedicated facilities. Many thanks to our airport frontline workers for keeping Singapore safe!

Visited Changi Airport with Minister @gankimyong last week to meet our frontline workers, from immigration to healthcare, security and transport. They work hard to ensure that all returnees to Singapore are screened and isolated for 14-days, be it at home or in dedicated facilities. Many thanks to our airport frontline workers for keeping Singapore safe!

comments: Feedback : (Quote CNA news 6 Apr) " MOH said 25 more cases are linked to the cluster at S11 Dormitory @ Punggol, which has a total of 88 confirmed cases now.The cluster at Westlite Toh Guan dormitory now has a total of 29 confirmed cases linked to it, after one more case was identified in Monday's update. All 19,800 foreign workers housed at the two dorms would be quarantined in their rooms for the next 14 days, authorities announcedÂ on Sunday. " Analysis : quarantine for 14 days ? This is NOT good enough. I bet Singapore will get worse. If this is the method we use. Study how S. Korea and Taiwan do it. They dont take chances. Look, you have 19800 foreign workers quarantined for 14 days. Day 1 : say detected 5. Day 2 : no symptoms. Day 3. No symptoms. Day 4: detected 25 infected. So these silent 25 could have carried the virus since day 2. So by day 14 : if you released all into public, there will bound to have some that are"silently" infected with no symptoms that were affected by A from day 1 to B in day 2 then to C D E F in day 5 and XXXXX in day 13....etc. 19800 foreign workers ? Very very serious consequences. Correct way to do it ? Like what S. Korea did. Like what WHO said : Test Test Test. MOH have this chance to test all 19800 now that they are being quarantined. Just do it. For the safety of all locals. If you dont test and released them all after day 14, and say 5% are silent carriers (about 900 infected pax released into the public), I think it will be catastropic for Singapore. Dear Minister, you are working hard, no doubt about it. Aprreciate that. But please think twice about the current strategy MOH is deploying. Is really not good enough. Especially for these huge group of 19800 pax. Thank you. @leehsienloong@gankimyong@ongyekung @teocheehean @ng.chee.meng @khawboonwan Note : 19800 in 2 dorms ? Singapore hopefully can learn something from the Cruise Ships case studies / experiences. They were released after quarantine with NO symptoms. Afterwhich ? Many were found infected after released into the public. So answer / solution is : Test Test Test. Test all 19800. S. Korea and Taiwan really do a good job as what we seen so far.
description: Visited Changi Airport with Minister @gankimyong last week to meet our frontline workers, from immigration to healthcare, security and transport. They work hard to ensure that all returnees to Singapore are screened and isolated for 14-days, be it at home or in dedicated facilities. Many thanks to our airport frontline workers for keeping Singapore safe!

comments: Feedback to the Ministerial Taskforce : Remember this. Wuhan started with a few. Then a few hundred. Then a few thousand. Then tens of thousands. And a few hundred / a few thousands infected China nationals then went all over the world. And now ? More than 1.2 mil infected. UK, Italy, Spain, France, USA the same stories. It all started with a few, then a few hundred. And then ? Exploded. Out of Control. Like Italy. Like Spain and etc. Singapore started with a few. Now ? More than a thousand. There were "many overlook" Singapore Govt made. One of them : letting in tens of thousands of Malaysians before Malaysia borders lockdown. My feel is? Singapore Govt tried to balance $ making (aka economy) with virus crisis management. So a bit here . A bit there. Some good measures here. Some loopholes there. In the end ? We get to "nowhere". Is our economy intact by "this balancing act" ? No. Because is serious now, we have this "circuit breaker" (much like a lockdown). Our economy went from bad (in Jan) to worse (in Apr) . My frank assessment is this : what "saved" Singapore from "explosion phase" is : our very good healthcare systems. BUT bear in mind, once the community spread get out of control, from a thousand can easily shoot up to tens of thousands. Touchwood. Should that happen, not even Singapore World Class healthcare systems can save Singapore residents. Singapore would be like Italy. Spain. USA. I am sad, worried, very disappointed. Yes we have good Govt. But I feel our Govt was "too complacent". Initially our Govt countered it like SARS. Flashback (CNA 1 Feb) : Dr Brenda Ang : â€œWe have a few SARS veterans here. One of the things I said at the first briefings (for the Wuhan coronavirus) was donâ€™t worry, we have been through this before. We can handle it.â€â€œI saw Singapore'sÂ first SARS case, Iâ€™m still alive and standing,â€ she said. On how widespread the Wuhan coronavirus is likely to be, Dr Ang said current literature suggests that even people who are exposed to the virus do not necessarily get infected.â€œIt probably isnâ€™t that infectious, (even though) people are wearing surgical masks all over the place.â€ (UNQUOTE). @leehsienloong@gankimyong@ongyekung

comments: FEEDBACK/SHARING OF WORLD NEWS : latest news (CNN) : (QUOTE) Austria "The wearing of face masks in supermarkets will become compulsory from Wednesday, Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz announced.''As of the moment these masks are handed out in front of the supermarkets and it will become compulsory to wear them in supermarkets'', Kurz said, adding that ''the goal is in the medium term to not only wear these masks in supermarkets but also more generally wherever people have contact with each other''Â " . (UNQUOTE) It is our Govt's job to do it (ensuring enough masks for the people to wear in public e.g. in crowded mrts and buses). Whether is it buying from China or setting up a factory to produce masks, just do it. Wearing masks definitely is effective in the overall containment efforts. You cannot have 1 good measure in say foodcourts distancing control and then "overlook or fail" in another area : e.g. mrt , buses. If so, the overall containment efforts will not be as effective. @leehsienloong@lawrencewongst@khawboonwan @gankimyong @ongyekung @teocheehean So in my opinion, our Govt have done a good job in many areas but "overlook, fail or loophole" in other areas. This is not good enough for the overall containment effectiveness.

description:
Todayâ€™s Straits Times has a good graphic to illustrate the underlying reasons for the recent rise in our infected cases. Most of these are imported cases - specifically Singapore residents coming back from overseas. We welcome them back. At the same time, we must make sure that any infected cases are quickly identified and ring-fenced, so as to minimise the risk of local transmission.

This is why our main focus now is to ensure that all such returnees self-isolate for 14 days at home. To avoid compounding the issue, Singapore residents should not make any new plans to travel. We must all do our part to keep ourselves, our families, and our fellow citizens safe during this crisis.

Source: The Straits Times Â©ï¸ Singapore Press Holdings Limited. Permission required for reproduction

comments: Dear minister Wong thanks for your hard work. But I must say it isnâ€™t a good idea to have the Singaporean/resident returnees serve their SHN at home. I just saw a CNA clip - reporter was doing interview with a pair of sisters who HAD just returned from the UK at their home :(( This is a prime eg why a quarantine at home wonâ€™t work. Some people are just not going to abide by the rules to stay inside their rooms at all times (except to use shower/toilet) the moment they reach home from the airport. Members of the family are inevitably exposed who then go on to infect others in the public. We should follow HK , send returnees to govt facilities. We did that with our Wuhan returnees so why not for this group since Europe now is the new epicenter?

comments: LOA is not = Stay Home Notice. For those travel returnees on LOA, if they are infected and they go out to the public community, e.g. packed supermakets , packed hawker centres, packed mcdonald's, packed malls, there is a likelihood of an "Uncontrollable BreakOut" caused by these travel returnees on LOA who may be infected. If a hawker doing say popiah is being infected by the infected, and if she continues to roll her popiahs with some mild symptoms, and unaware consumers eat them, the chance of infection is there. If that happens, all these contact tracing apps will not be that relevant anymore. If Singapore becomes the next Italy, it will be "too late". Singapore will then be in a very disastrous situation. Economy will be 10X maybe 100X worse than the current bad situation. Bear in mind this : Singapore society is closely compact and one of the world's highest density population. Can you afford to close down all mrts and bus servicces like what China did. We must take a pre-emptive approach in anticipation of "the worst possible scenario" and instead of "let's see how then react" . The latter was what Italy , many European countries did. They waited to see how to react. When the crisis exploded suddenly and situation out of control, then they react. But, it was "too late" That isÂ  fire fighting approach, not fire prevention. I worry a lot. For families, friends, fellow Singaporeans. Reason : Indonesia. I guess Indonesia will be the next Italy due to their "reported behaviour e.g. attend large groupings even when their Govt bans them" as well as "their Govt citing high costs this high costs that even for Covid-19 testing for many of their potential patients". Once Indonesia explodes like Italy, I dont think they can do containment as well as "exploded Korea". Singapore being its closest neighbor will be in a very very serious, dangerous and risky situation. Will our Govt take our feedback seriously ? We feedback not to curry favors (unlike many instagrammers), get likes attention and so forth. We feedback our concerns because we genuinely care. @lawrencewongst @gankimyong @leehsienloong @hengsweekeat @teocheehean @khawboonwan @ongyekung @vivianbalakrishnan

comments: Dear Minister Wong, Iâ€™m very glad to know that returnees from the UK and USA will have to serve SHN at designated hotels starting on Thursday (although itâ€™d have been better to apply to everyone). Though itâ€™s late, itâ€™s the right move forward. Everyone should be treated as a suspect case and be tested upon arrival, and not just those who present symptoms at the border (which I believe is the protocol now). Mass testing has proven to be the tipping point for South Korea. We need to nip it in the bud - test, isolate, treat. Time is crucial, we canâ€™t afford to wait for symptoms to show up then have patients present themselves at the hospital. If we can gift the Philippines with 3000 test kits surely we can do it for our fellow returnees? Also, at this point we should make it mandatory to wear mask. Wearing one is essential in the fight -  just look at China, Taiwan, SK, HK. â€œWear one only when youâ€™re sickâ€ is not medically correct at this point in time. Experts in China have said people shed virus even before symptoms are present. Only by wearing a mask can we protect ourselves and people around us. I know thereâ€™s a shortage of masks in Singapore which makes it unfortunate but we can use cloth recyclable masks or any home made ones. When everyone wears one, it doesnâ€™t matter if oneâ€™s quality is better than another. It really has helped those countries in containment. Thatâ€™s certain. But to tell people that healthy people donâ€™t need to wear one is just plain wrong, pardon me for saying. Iâ€™m writing as a concerned Singaporean - we must look at the above countries and learn from them. My next worry is when Malaysia ends her lockdown and thousands of people start to cross the causeway into Singapore... since itâ€™s been proven with our recent imported cases that most donâ€™t show symptoms at the border (meaning temperature can no longer be used as a gauge), how then? Thank you and the team once again for the hard work. We appreciate it and to the frontliners who are doing such a incredible job , itâ€™s going to be a much tougher fight but together we shall overcome.

We have introduced a new 14-day Stay Home Notice for all travellers (Singaporeans, PRs, and long-term pass holders) coming back from China. This will replace the Leave of Absence or LOA arrangement. 
Under the new regime, all returnees will have to stay at home or their designated accommodation (eg dormitory or hostel) throughout the 14 day period. They will not be allowed to go out. We will enforce this strictly using a range of technological tools and manual spot checks, and there will be penalties for all who breach the rules. 
This additional measures will help to minimise the number of new imported cases, and allow us to focus our energies and efforts on reducing the risks of local transmission within our own community.

comments: We need the cooperation and efforts of all such travellers to make this scheme successful. I hope that there is close monitoring to ensure their compliance. Meantime, I hope that their needs such as meals and essentials can be delivered to them so that they are well taken care of and do not need to leave their residences.

description:
Volunteers all ready for collection of masks in Limbang this afternoon. We are starting with our studio apartments and rental blocks to give priority to elderly and vulnerable groups. But all will be able to collect over the coming days. 
You can check this website for more information - Go.gov.sg/maskcollection

We are ushering the Year of the Rat with concerns of the Wuhan virus hanging over us. But rest assured the Government is sparing no effort to deal with this issue. Meanwhile let us all keep calm, maintain good hygiene habits and continue our new year celebrations with our family and loved ones. 
Much of the CNY festivities will take place at our homes, be it reunion dinners tonight or house visits over the next few days. On MNDâ€™s part, we remain committed to providing affordable and quality homes for all Singaporeans, just as we have done over the past 60 years. 
Happy Chinese New Year everyone!

The Wuhan virus situation has escalated rapidly in the last few days. Thatâ€™s why MOH has set up a Multi-Ministry Taskforce to deal with this issue, and Health Minister Gan Kim Yong has asked me to co-chair the Taskforce with him.

The Government will spare no effort to defend and protect Singapore and Singaporeans. We stand ready to marshal all our resources towards this end. But the most important defence is for us to be psychologically prepared. We must stay calm and carry on with our lives. We must be prepared that, despite our best defences, it is a matter of time before we see imported cases here and be ready to mount a swift and effective response. Ultimately we must all stay alert and vigilant; and continue to work together to deal with this rapidly evolving situation. With that mindset, we can overcome any outbreak and respond to any eventuality.
